key_title: Key to the genera of Rutaceae

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Dicotyledons

source.author: Duretto, M.F.
source.title: Rutaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae
source.citation: From: Duretto, M.F. (1999). Rutaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 4. Cornaceae to Asteraceae. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Leaves opposite, rarely subopposite and then leaves not mucronate, simple or pinnate; flowers 4-merous
Leaves alternate, simple; flowers 5-merous or rarely 4-merous and then leaves mucronate
Stamens 4; disc with 4 gland-like lobes; leaves trifoliolate or simple, margin usually recurved
Stamens 8, rarely 4 or 6 but then leaves simple and plane; disc entire and smooth; leaves simple or pinnate
Petals 1–5 cm long, usually cohering to form a cylindrical tube
Petals to 1 cm long, free to base
Trees or shrubs; leaves usually simple, rarely trifoliolate; fruit indehiscent, succu- lent; stamens spreading; rainforests of East Gippsland
Bushes or herbs or rarely a small tree and then leaves pinnate; leaves simple or pinnate; fruit explosively dehiscent, dry; stamens erect; widespread
[link through]

Tip of petal with small but distinct incurved hook; anther connective usually prominent and dark coloured; flowers axillary or if terminal on long shoots then flowers often blue; seeds dull, rugose to minutely verrucose
Tip of petal straight; anther connective usually cream-coloured and inconspicuous; flowers terminal or axillary; seeds shiny or dull, smooth or only minutely tuberculate
Flowers minute, sessile and in terminal heads; carpels 2; leaves less than 8 mm long, terete; stamens 10; ericoid shrubs of mallee
Flowers conspicuous and not in terminal heads; carpels 5; leaves mostly greater than 8 mm long; stamens 5 or 10; widespread
Stamens 5; staminodes 0 or 5
Stamens 10; staminodes absent
Erect, rounded shrub with ericoid leaves; 5 staminodes present and these adnate to the petals
Small tree with weeping leaves and branches; staminodes absent
[link through]
[link through]
Anthers with a sterile white apiculum, sometimes minute; stamens ciliate, pyramidally arranged and incurved over ovary
Anthers without apiculum (small gland may be present); stamens glabrous, spreading
Anthers pilose
Anthers glabrous
[link through]
Leaves glabrous or variously hairy, but lower surfaces, sepals etc. not invested with peltate scales
At least abaxial surfaces of leaves (and usually calyces and petals) invested with peltate scales
Sepals minute, largely hidden amongst conspicuous and abundant stellate hairs; petals mostly bright yellow; stigma peltate, conspicuously wider than style
Sepals obvious, stellate hairs, if present, small and inconcpicuous; petals  white or cream (rarely pink); stigma scarsely differentiated from style
Inflorescences umbellate, terminal; petals mostly yellow (whitish in P. festivum of goldfields)
Inflorescences axillary (sometimes terminal also), of solitary flowers or few-flowered cymes; petals white
